Sovereignty of God.name: The Sovereignty of God
Sovereignty of God.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: 'Behold, I have given you every plant yielding seed which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree with seed in its fruit; ...' In the statement above, God made all provision for man to:
questions.explanation: This statement from Genesis 1:29 demonstrates God's sovereignty as the ultimate provider. By His authoritative decree, He designated all seed-bearing plants and fruit trees as food for humanity, establishing the basis of human sustenance.

questions.question: God told Noah that 'Whoever sheds the blood of man, by man shall his blood be shed; ...' because:
options: Man is made in God's image.
Blood is the life of man.
questions.explanation: This command (Genesis 9:6) establishes the sacredness of human life under God's sovereign rule. The authority to require a life for a life is rooted in God's unique creation of humanity in His own image, making an attack on a person an affront to God's supreme authority.

questions.question: What did God promise the Israelites after their rescue from Babylon to make them fear Him forever?
options: A new heart and a new life.
A new covenant and a new spirit.
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 32:39-40, God sovereignly promises to give His people 'one heart and one way,' ensuring their eternal fear of Him. This shows His supreme power not only to deliver but to transform hearts, guaranteeing their future loyalty.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah's prophecy, the domination of nations by Nebuchadnezzar was:
options: The result of his military might.
The result of the wickedness of nations.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 27:5-6 declares, 'I have given all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar... and all the nations shall serve him.' This asserts God's absolute sovereignty, using even pagan empires as instruments to fulfill His divine judgment and purpose.

questions.question: What was the condition of the earth before the creation of the world?
options: The earth was without form and void.
There was a firmament above the earth.
The earth was inhabited by angels and spirits.
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:2 describes the earth as 'without form and void.' This establishes God's sovereignty as the uncaused first cause. He did not organize pre-existing matter but exercised supreme creative authority over primordial chaos, bringing order from nothingness.

questions.question: Before Moses died, God appointed ... to succeed him.
questions.explanation: Numbers 27:18 records God's direct command to Moses: 'Take Joshua... a man in whom is the Spirit.' The succession was not by human choice or lineage but by God's sovereign appointment, demonstrating His control over Israel's leadership.

questions.question: At childhood, the word of the Lord came to Samuel because he:
options: Had the qualities of a prophet.
Was to announce the punishment for the house of Eli.
questions.explanation: God's sovereign initiative is highlighted in 1 Samuel 3. He chose to reveal His judgment to Samuel, a child, bypassing the established priest Eli. This shows that God's communication is at His discretion to fulfill His purposes.

questions.topic_focus: Sovereignty Declared in a Sacred Place
questions.question: 'This is none other than the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven,' was said by:
questions.explanation: After his dream of the ladder, Jacob declared this at Bethel (Genesis 28:17). The statement acknowledges the location as a point where God sovereignly chose to reveal His heavenly authority and presence on earth.

questions.question: In the beginning, God created the:
questions.explanation: The opening verse of the Bible (Genesis 1:1) is the foundational declaration of God's sovereignty. It establishes His absolute authority as the creator of the totality of existence—'the heavens and the earth'—from which everything else derives.

questions.question: King Rehoboam refused to take the counsel of the elders because:
options: He was afraid of the outcome of their counsel.
It was a turn of affairs brought about by the LORD.
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:15 states that Rehoboam's foolish rejection of wise counsel 'was a turn of affairs brought about by the Lord.' This reveals God's sovereignty over human decisions, using them to fulfill His prophetic word (through Ahijah) concerning the kingdom's division.

questions.question: According to Prophet Isaiah, the creative ability of God is likened to that of a:
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8 says, 'We are the clay, and you are our potter.' This metaphor powerfully illustrates God's sovereign authority to shape, mold, and determine the fate of nations and individuals according to His will, just as a potter has absolute control over the clay.

questions.question: The declaration by God that he would make a nation of the son of the slave woman meant that He:
options: Was not partial towards Isaac and Ishmael.
Did not like the way Ishmael was sent out by Abraham.
Was responsible for sending Ishmael out of Abraham's house.
questions.explanation: God's promise to Hagar concerning Ishmael (Genesis 21:13) reaffirms His sovereign prerogative to establish nations according to His will, not merely human lineage. It shows His authority extends over and blesses all families of the earth, even outside the chosen line.

questions.question: 'Let us make man in our image, after our likeness...' In the statement above, 'in our image' implies man:
options: Being a representative of God and fellow men.
Becoming the exact picture of God.
questions.explanation: Being made in God's image (Genesis 1:26) confers a derived, representative authority. It means humans are created to be God's vice-regents on earth, exercising dominion under His supreme sovereignty as His authorized representatives.

questions.topic_focus: Sovereign Use of Nations for Judgment
questions.question: One of the sins of Manasseh for which the LORD sent bands of the Chaldeans, Syrians, Moabites and Ammonites to destroy Judah was:
options: The release of a thousand captives.
His failure to obey God's prophets.
The arrest of the King of Babylon.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 24:3-4 attributes Judah's fall to Manasseh's sins, especially 'the innocent blood that he had shed.' This demonstrates God's sovereignty in directing the armies of foreign nations as instruments of His judgment against His own people for their covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: Elijah decreed that there would be neither rain nor dew for three years because:
options: Ahab had forsaken the commandment of God by erecting an altar for Baal.
Nebat the son of Rehoboam connived with Ahab to kill him.
He was sure that he would be fed by the ravens.
Jezebel the wife of Ahab killed Obadiah.
questions.explanation: Elijah's declaration of drought (1 Kings 17:1) was a direct exercise of God's sovereign authority over creation to confront idolatry. It proved that Yahweh, not Baal (the Canaanite storm god), controlled the rain and fertility of the land.

questions.question: God called Jonah and sent him to the people of Nineveh to:
options: Pray to Him for their forgiveness.
questions.explanation: God's command to Jonah (Jonah 1:2) highlights His sovereignty over all nations, not just Israel. He has the absolute authority to appoint a prophet and send a message of judgment to any people, regardless of the prophet's personal feelings.

Covenant.name: Covenant
Covenant.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: Which of the following is the sign of the covenant between God and Abraham?
options: The sprinkling of blood on door posts.
Circumcision in the flesh of the foreskins.
questions.explanation: The sign of the everlasting covenant between God and Abraham and his descendants was circumcision (Genesis 17:10-11). This physical sign marked them as God's chosen people.

questions.question: The covenant was renewed on Mount Sinai because
options: there was a new generation which did not remember the first.
the people had taken part in Korah's rebellion.
the people had demanded water from the rock.
the people had wanted to return to Egypt.
questions.explanation: Before entering the Promised Land, Moses rehearsed the law with the new generation that had grown up in the wilderness, renewing the covenant made at Sinai with their fathers (Deuteronomy 5:2-3).

questions.question: As a condition of his covenant with God, Abraham had to
questions.explanation: The covenant between God and Abraham had the specific sign of circumcision for all males as its condition and physical mark (Genesis 17:10-14).

questions.question: When did the Israelites say 'All that the Lord has spoken we will do'?
options: When Moses spoke to them before his death.
After the incident of the golden calf.
questions.explanation: This declaration was made by the Israelites at Mount Sinai, signifying their acceptance of the Mosaic Covenant and their commitment to obey God's laws (Exodus 19:8).

questions.question: The sign of the covenant between God and Noah for all future generations was
questions.explanation: After the Flood, God set His rainbow in the cloud as the sign of His everlasting covenant with all flesh, promising never again to destroy the earth by water (Genesis 9:12-13).

questions.question: What did God promise the Israelites after their rescue from Babylon to make them fear Him forever?
options: A new heart and a new life.
A new covenant and a new spirit.
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 32:39-40, God promises the future new covenant: 'I will give them one heart and one way, that they may fear me forever, for their own good and the good of their children after them.'

questions.question: The Lord appeared to Abraham and promised his descendants the land of the Canaanites at
questions.explanation: God first appeared to Abram at Shechem, by the oak of Moreh, and promised to give the land of Canaan to his offspring (Genesis 12:6-7).

questions.question: The new covenant God made with the house of Israel and the house of Judah was written on
questions.explanation: Jeremiah prophesied about the new covenant where God's law would be written on hearts rather than on tablets of stone (Jeremiah 31:33).

questions.question: During the confirmation of the covenant, Moses was invited by the Lord along with
questions.explanation: When confirming the covenant, Moses went up with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and seventy elders of Israel to worship at a distance (Exodus 24:1, 9).

questions.question: The Lord said to Moses: 'Cut two tablets of stone like the first; and I will write upon the tablets the words that were upon the first tablets which you broke.' On what occasion was this said?
options: At the renewal of the Covenant.
Just before the election of Joshua.
After the first fall of Manna from heaven.
questions.explanation: This occurred after the incident of the golden calf when Moses interceded for the people and God renewed the covenant with Israel (Exodus 34:1-4).

questions.question: The prophet who proclaimed a new covenant of God with Israel and Judah was
questions.explanation: Jeremiah specifically prophesied about the new covenant that God would make with the house of Israel and Judah (Jeremiah 31:31-34).

questions.question: God appeared to Jacob in a dream and Jacob made a vow to
questions.explanation: After his dream of the ladder at Bethel, Jacob made a vow that if God would be with him, then 'of all that you give me I will give a full tenth to you' (Genesis 28:20-22).

questions.question: '...And they shall be my people, and I will be their God...' This covenant was made with Israel through prophet
questions.explanation: This is part of Jeremiah's new covenant prophecy where God promises restoration and a renewed relationship with His people (Jeremiah 31:33).

questions.question: 'All the words which the Lord has spoken we will do.' What was Moses' response to this declaration by the Israelites?
options: He asked them to pick twelve stones to represent the tribes.
He offered peace offerings to the LORD.
He charged them to walk faithfully before the LORD.
He said that the LORD was witness to their declaration.
questions.explanation: Moses reported the people's words to the Lord, and the Lord acknowledged their commitment as the basis for the covenant relationship (Exodus 19:8-9).

Leadership qualities.name: Leadership Qualities
Leadership qualities.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: Who was chosen to lead the Israelites after Moses' death?
questions.explanation: Joshua was appointed by God to succeed Moses, demonstrating divinely ordained leadership succession (Numbers 27:18-20).

questions.question: 'Now therefore, fear the Lord and serve him in sincerity... put away the gods which your fathers served... and serve the Lord.' This charge was given by:
questions.explanation: Joshua's final charge (Joshua 24:14) exemplifies spiritual leadership that directs people to God rather than self.

questions.question: Samuel's sons were rejected as judges because they
options: were not from the royal family
the Israelites wanted to be like other people who had kings
questions.explanation: Their corruption (1 Samuel 8:3) shows how failed leadership undermines public trust and can lead to systemic change.

questions.question: Each of the spies sent out by Moses on God's command to report on the nature of the Promised Land was a
questions.explanation: Leaders should be selected from among respected representatives of their communities (Numbers 13:2).

questions.question: God took the Kingdom from Saul because he
options: did not offer sacrifices to the Lord
disobeyed the Lord by offering burnt sacrifices himself
questions.explanation: Saul's unauthorized sacrifice (1 Samuel 13:8-14) demonstrates that leaders must operate within God-given boundaries.

questions.question: What did the Apostles do when complaints were made to them that some sections of the new Christian community were not being supplied with their needs for sustenance?
options: gave out more money for buying food
said that they had neither gold nor silver
appointed seven deacons to undertake the care of the new Christians
appointed the Apostles: James, Peter and John to oversee the supply
questions.explanation: Effective leaders delegate appropriate tasks to maintain focus on primary responsibilities (Acts 6:1-6).

questions.question: 'Whoever rebels against your commandment and disobeys your words, whatever you command him, shall be put to death: only be strong and of good courage.' The above passage was addressed to:
questions.explanation: Leadership requires courage to exercise rightful authority with the support of followers (Joshua 1:18).

questions.question: Saul was made king publicly before the Lord and before all the people of Israel at
questions.explanation: Public affirmation establishes a leader's accountability to both God and people (1 Samuel 11:15).

questions.question: In the case before Solomon over the dead and the living child, the mother of the dead child supported
options: giving the living child to her opponent
joint ownership of the living child
king Solomon having the living child
questions.explanation: Solomon's wisdom revealed truth through understanding human nature (1 Kings 3:16-28).

questions.topic_focus: The Peril of Rejecting Wise Counsel
questions.question: To whom was this addressed? 'Your father made our yoke heavy. Now therefore lighten the hard service of your father and his heavy yoke upon us and we will serve you.'
questions.explanation: Rehoboam's rejection of elder wisdom for peer advice caused kingdom division (1 Kings 12).

questions.question: 'Grant us to sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your glory.' The petitioners were
questions.explanation: Jesus taught that true leadership is service, not seeking honor (Mark 10:35-45).

questions.question: King David committed adultery with
questions.explanation: David's sin shows leaders' moral vulnerability and how private failings have public consequences (2 Samuel 11).

questions.question: 'Alas, my daughter: you have brought me very low and you have become the cause of great trouble to me for I have opened my mouth to the Lord, and I cannot take back my vow.' Who said this?
questions.explanation: Jephthah's rash vow illustrates the heavy responsibility of a leader's words (Judges 11:30-35).

questions.question: The commander of David's army was
questions.explanation: Joab's mixed legacy shows that capable subordinates need careful management by leaders.

questions.question: 'Rule over us you and your son and your grandson also, for you have delivered us out of the hand of Midian.' This request was addressed to
questions.explanation: Gideon rightly refused to establish a dynasty, acknowledging God as Israel's true ruler (Judges 8:22-23).

questions.question: Those inspired by God to lead the tribes of Israel in battle were the
questions.explanation: The judges were charismatic leaders raised by God to deliver and govern Israel in times of crisis.

questions.question: 'Which is better for you that all seventy of the sons of Jerubbaal rule over you, or that one rule over you?' Who asked this question?
questions.explanation: Jotham's fable challenged Abimelech's illegitimate kingship, showing how leaders can be held accountable through public discourse.

questions.question: 'Cursed be the man who takes food before evening before I am able to avenge myself on my enemies.' This was said by Saul during the battle between Israel and the
questions.explanation: Saul's rash oath during battle (1 Samuel 14:24) endangered his troops and son Jonathan, showing how impulsive leadership decisions can backfire.

questions.question: The suggestion made by prophet Nathan to Bathsheba to foil Adonijah's attempt to usurp the throne of David was to
options: remind David of his promise that Solomon would succeed him
have Solomon secretly anointed by Zadok
plead with Adonijah to abandon the attempt
questions.explanation: Nathan's intervention ensured an orderly, promised succession, showing how advisors can help leaders fulfill commitments.

questions.question: How many months were the Israelites on forced labour in Lebanon allowed to spend at home for every month at the labour camp?
questions.explanation: Solomon's harsh labor policies (1 Kings 5:13-14) sowed seeds of discontent that contributed to the kingdom's later division.

questions.question: Which of the following Kings said 'Behold your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt?'
questions.explanation: Jeroboam I established idol worship to secure his political position, leading Israel into systemic sin (1 Kings 12:28).

questions.question: When the Queen of Sheba heard Solomon's fame concerning the name of the Lord, she came to test him with her
questions.explanation: Leaders are tested by their wisdom and knowledge, not just power or wealth (1 Kings 10:1).

questions.question: The greatest of David's domestic problems that seemed to break his heart was the
questions.explanation: Absalom's rebellion was the ultimate family betrayal and political crisis, testing David's leadership profoundly.

questions.question: Besides the gifts of wisdom, what other gift did the Lord promise to Solomon but with a condition?
questions.explanation: God promised Solomon long life conditional on obedience (1 Kings 3:14), showing that leaders' blessings are tied to faithfulness.

questions.question: Which prophet encouraged Jeroboam I to revolt at the initial stage?
questions.explanation: Ahijah prophesied the kingdom's division to Jeroboam (1 Kings 11:29-31), showing how prophets sometimes endorse political change.

questions.question: The city of Samaria was built by
questions.explanation: Omri established a new capital, Samaria, as a political and military center, leaving an architectural legacy (1 Kings 16:24).

questions.question: As David was about to die, he charged Solomon to keep God's statutes, commandments, ordinances and testimonies, so that he, Solomon, might
options: prosper and the Davidic dynasty be preserved forever
have children who would succeed him
questions.explanation: David's final charge emphasized that the dynasty's continuation depended on covenant faithfulness, not just political power.

questions.question: 'Then the spirit of the Lord will come mightily upon you, and you shall prophesy with them ...' This was said to
questions.explanation: Samuel told Saul the Spirit would confirm his leadership (1 Samuel 10:6), showing divine empowerment as a leadership marker.

questions.question: The evil spirit that tormented Saul left him whenever he
questions.explanation: Saul's dependence on David's music shows leaders' vulnerability and need for support from others.

questions.question: In the trade treaty between king Solomon and Hiram of Lebanon, Solomon was to supply wheat and oil while Hiram was to supply
questions.explanation: Solomon's agreement with Hiram (1 Kings 5:1-12) shows leadership through international diplomacy and resource management.

questions.question: Elkanah went to worship and to sacrifice to the LORD at Shiloh
questions.explanation: Elkanah's annual pilgrimage modeled consistent religious observance for his family, a form of spiritual leadership.

questions.topic_focus: Loyalty and Duty Over Personal Comfort
questions.question: Uriah did not wish to go down to his house because
options: Joab would set him in the forefront of the battle
the Ark was in the battlefield
questions.explanation: Uriah's commitment to fellow soldiers while the Ark was in the field contrasts with David's self-indulgence, showing different leadership ethics.

questions.question: Who advised the Sanhedrin to keep away from the apostles and let them alone?
questions.explanation: Gamaliel's counsel (Acts 5:34-39) showed wisdom in not opposing what might be God's work, a prudent leadership approach.

questions.question: 'For I am ready not only to be imprisoned but even to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.' Who was this devoted person?
questions.explanation: Paul's determination despite warnings (Acts 21:13) shows leadership as commitment to mission above personal safety.

questions.question: When Paul came to Rome, the first set of people to whom he preached were the
questions.explanation: Paul's strategy of 'to the Jew first' (Romans 1:16) showed principled leadership in mission approach.

questions.question: Joshua was appointed to lead the Israelites to the Promised Land because
options: Moses was too old to lead them there
the Israelites preferred Joshua to Moses
of Moses' rebellion in the wilderness of Zin
questions.explanation: Joshua's appointment resulted from Moses' failure at Meribah, showing how leadership transitions sometimes follow failure.

questions.question: 'My little finger is thicker than my father's loins' means that in comparison with his father
questions.explanation: Rehoboam's threat of harsher rule (1 Kings 12:10-11) exemplified arrogant, autocratic leadership that rejects wise counsel.

questions.question: The seven deacons were appointed to
options: conduct a mission to the Gentiles
help in the distribution of food
questions.explanation: The appointment of deacons (Acts 6:1-6) shows organizational leadership that addresses practical needs to maintain unity.

questions.question: Paul standing in the Areopagus, used the teaching of the poets of the people to introduce God the Creator at
questions.explanation: Paul's Mars Hill address (Acts 17:22-28) shows leadership in contextualizing message without compromising truth.

divine providence.name: Divine Providence, Guidance and Protection
divine providence.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: Joseph saw his sale by his brothers as God's plan to enable him to
questions.explanation: Joseph recognized God's providential hand, telling his brothers, 'You meant evil against me, but God meant it for good, to save many people alive' (Genesis 50:20).

questions.topic_focus: Divine Protection at the Red Sea
questions.question: '...The Lord will fight for you, and you have only to be still...' This statement was made by Moses when the
options: Egyptians were pursuing the Israelites before the Red Sea
Israelites were standing before King Pharaoh
Israelites' chariots were crossing the Red Sea
questions.explanation: At the Red Sea crisis, Moses assured Israel of God's protective intervention, demonstrating faith in divine providence during impossible situations (Exodus 14:13-14).

questions.question: The jar of meal shall not be spent and the cruse of oil shall not fail, until the day that the Lord sends rain upon the earth. From the context, which of these statements is UNTRUE?
options: The meal in the jar and the oil in the cruse were continually replenished thereafter
The widow of Zarephath prepared food for Elijah
The widow and her son ate the food and waited for their death
The woman was gathering sticks to prepare her last meal
questions.explanation: God miraculously sustained the widow, her son, and Elijah throughout the famine, showing His providential care extends beyond immediate needs (1 Kings 17:8-16).

questions.question: Which country in Africa provided Jesus with a refuge when Herod sought to destroy him?
questions.explanation: God providentially guided Joseph to take Jesus to Egypt for protection, fulfilling Hosea's prophecy about God calling His Son out of Egypt (Matthew 2:13-15).

questions.question: What was the immediate reaction of Moses when he cast his rod on the ground at Mount Horeb and it became a serpent?
options: He took it by the tail
questions.explanation: Moses' initial fear shows human vulnerability, yet God's providential plan continued through the miraculous signs that authenticated Moses' calling (Exodus 4:3).

questions.question: When Joseph discovered that his betrothed Mary was with child, he decided to divorce her quietly because
options: Mary was too tender and lovely
the angel warned Joseph not to be harsh on Mary
questions.explanation: Joseph's planned quiet divorce showed mercy, but God providentially intervened through a dream to guide him rightly (Matthew 1:19-20).

questions.question: On the first day when the Israelites left part of the bread, it bred worms and became foul, but on the sixth day when they left part of the bread it did not become foul because
options: God commanded them to keep it
Moses wanted to save them the trouble of searching for bread everyday
by then they had discovered a better way of preserving it
questions.explanation: The manna's different behavior on the sixth day showed God's providential planning for the Sabbath, teaching dependence on His provision (Exodus 16:19-24).

questions.question: One of the reasons why Sennacherib could not enter Jerusalem and conquer it as he did to Samaria was that
options: his god told him to return home from his camp
thousands of his soldiers miraculously died overnight
he willingly changed his mind and returned to his country
fight broke out among his soldiers
questions.explanation: God's angel struck down 185,000 Assyrian soldiers, miraculously protecting Jerusalem without human battle (2 Kings 19:35).

questions.question: Joseph's rough treatment of his brothers was to
options: assure himself that they were not spies
questions.explanation: Joseph tested his brothers to see if they had changed, guided by God's providence to achieve reconciliation (Genesis 42-45).

questions.question: The possibility of crossing the Red Sea was seen by Israel as
options: God's active presence in their midst
the miraculous power of Moses' rod
questions.explanation: The miraculous crossing demonstrated God's protective presence guiding and delivering His people (Exodus 14:31).

questions.question: Moses sent men to spy out the land of Canaan in order to
options: know if it was good or bad
know if it was flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: God commanded the reconnaissance mission to guide Israel's approach to the Promised Land, though the people misinterpreted the report (Numbers 13:1-2).

questions.question: Rahab's reward for hiding the messengers sent by Joshua to spy out the city of Jericho was that
options: she and her household were spared
the city of Jericho was spared for her sake
she married one of the spies and became a queen
the gold, bronze and iron in the city were given to her
questions.explanation: God protected Rahab and her family because of her faith and assistance, showing His providential care extends to those who align with His purposes (Joshua 6:25).

questions.question: David's victory over the Amalekites who raided Ziklag was due to
options: the fact that David was a mighty man in battle
his swearing to the Egyptian servant of the Amalekites not to kill or harm him
the great army that followed him to fight the Amalekites
his prayer in seeking the approval of God before pursuing them
questions.explanation: David sought God's guidance before pursuing the raiders, and God granted complete victory, showing dependence on divine direction (1 Samuel 30:8).

questions.question: God did not lead the Israelites by the way of the land of the Philistines although that was near because
options: He did not want them to see war and return to Egypt
The Egyptians would have overtaken them
They were afraid of the Philistines
He wanted them to learn through hardship in the wilderness
questions.explanation: God providentially guided Israel on a longer route to avoid immediate warfare that might discourage them, showing His protective wisdom (Exodus 13:17-18).

questions.question: The two Hebrew midwives instructed by Pharaoh to kill the Hebrew male babies at birth were
questions.explanation: God providentially used the courageous midwives Shiphrah and Puah to preserve Hebrew lives, blessing them for fearing God over Pharaoh (Exodus 1:15-21).

questions.question: When Elijah escaped from Ahab to the brook Cherith, he was fed by
questions.explanation: God miraculously used ravens to feed Elijah, showing His creative providence in sustaining His servants in wilderness places (1 Kings 17:4-6).

questions.question: The man appointed by the Holy Ghost to go on the missionary journey with Saul was
questions.explanation: The Holy Spirit specifically directed the church at Antioch to set apart Barnabas and Saul for missionary work, showing divine guidance in ministry partnerships (Acts 13:2).

questions.question: The Egyptian magicians were able to reproduce the first three miracles done by Moses and Aaron, but the fourth which they were unable to perform was the plague of
questions.explanation: The magicians' admission 'This is the finger of God' at the plague of gnats showed the limits of human power against divine providence (Exodus 8:16-19).

questions.question: During the voyage to Rome, some people thought that Paul was a god because
options: he was not harmed by a viper
questions.explanation: Paul's protection from the viper's bite on Malta demonstrated God's providential care over His servant, astonishing the islanders (Acts 28:3-6).

questions.question: 'Do not be afraid, but speak and do not be silent; for I am with you, and no man shall attack you to harm you; for I have many people in this city.' The city referred to was
questions.explanation: God encouraged Paul through a vision to continue ministering in Corinth despite opposition, promising His protective presence (Acts 18:9-10).

questions.question: On the Island of Malta, Paul healed a man who was
questions.explanation: Paul's healing of Publius' father demonstrated God's providential care opening ministry opportunities even during Paul's journey as a prisoner (Acts 28:7-9).

questions.question: The conversion of Paul was made possible by
questions.explanation: Paul's dramatic conversion resulted from a direct encounter with the risen Christ on the Damascus road, showing God's sovereign initiative in salvation (Acts 9:3-5).

questions.question: 'Now, I know that the Lord has sent his angel to deliver me out of the hand of Herod and from everything that the Jewish people expected to happen to me.' Who said this?
questions.explanation: Peter recognized his miraculous prison escape as God's protective intervention in answer to the church's prayers (Acts 12:11).

questions.question: Gideon was able to defeat the Midianites with a reduced number of soldiers because he
questions.explanation: God reduced Gideon's army to demonstrate that victory came from divine power, not human strength—a lesson in divine providence (Judges 7:2-7).

questions.question: The one who was to be the wife of Isaac was known
options: by her coming to the well to draw water
because she was a descendant of Abraham's brother
because she said 'Drink, and I will water your camels'
questions.explanation: Rebecca's kindness in watering the camels served as God's providential sign to Abraham's servant identifying the chosen wife for Isaac (Genesis 24:14).

questions.question: The evil spirit that tormented Saul left him whenever he
questions.explanation: God used David's musical skill to bring temporary relief to Saul, showing providential care even through human talents (1 Samuel 16:23).

questions.question: To the question of the Philippian Jailer, 'Men, what must I do to be saved?' Paul replied,
options: Confess your sins and give alms
Release us and wash our wounds
Trust in God and pray always
questions.explanation: After the earthquake that miraculously opened prison doors, Paul guided the jailer to salvation, showing how God uses crises for providential purposes (Acts 16:30-31).

questions.question: Moses fled Egypt to the land of Midian because
options: he was afraid that his crime would be made known
Pharaoh wanted to kill him for the crime he had committed
his countryman asked if he would also kill him
he had killed an Egyptian and buried him in the sand
questions.explanation: God providentially guided Moses to Midian for protection and preparation, though Moses fled out of fear (Exodus 2:15).

questions.question: In Exodus 17 and Numbers 20, similar incidents of lack of water for the congregation are recorded. A significant difference however, is that in Exodus 17, Moses is commanded to
questions.explanation: God provided water miraculously both times, but Moses' disobedience in striking rather than speaking at Meribah showed failure to follow specific divine guidance (Numbers 20:8-12).

questions.question: When Peter escaped from prison during the passover, the guards were
questions.explanation: God miraculously freed Peter despite maximum security, sending an angel while guards remained immobilized (Acts 12:6-7).

questions.question: Who prophesied a great famine over all the world at Antioch?
questions.explanation: Agabus' prophecy enabled the Antioch church to prepare for the famine providentially, showing how God guides His people through prophetic revelation (Acts 11:28).

questions.question: While Peter was still speaking, the holy Spirit fell on all who heard the word. Where did this happen?
questions.explanation: The Spirit fell on Cornelius' household while Peter preached, confirming God's providential inclusion of Gentiles into the church (Acts 10:44).

questions.question: Daniel was set up to be thrown to the lions by the
questions.explanation: Despite the conspiracy against him, God providentially protected Daniel in the lions' den, showing divine protection for the faithful (Daniel 6:7, 22).

questions.question: And the angel said to him, 'Dress yourself and put on your sandals.' The addressee was
questions.explanation: An angel guided Peter step-by-step during his miraculous prison escape, showing God's detailed providential care (Acts 12:8).

questions.question: The LORD sent Samuel to Saul to go and destroy the Amalekites because
options: they opposed Israel on their way out of Egypt
their land had been given to Israel after the battle
questions.explanation: God commanded the destruction of Amalek due to their ancient opposition to Israel, showing His providential protection of His people throughout generations (1 Samuel 15:2).

questions.question: The treatment for those bitten by the fiery serpent was to
questions.explanation: God provided healing through the bronze serpent to those who looked in faith, a foreshadowing of Christ's provision (Numbers 21:8-9).

questions.question: As David took to flight from Jerusalem on account of Absalom's conspiracy, he was apprehensive of the role of
questions.explanation: David recognized Ahitophel's dangerous counsel could defeat him, but God providentially turned the counsel to foolishness (2 Samuel 15:31).

questions.question: When Elisha received the message about Benhadad's ill-health, the prophet wept because
options: Benhadad would not recover from the sickness
Hazael would be cruel to Israel
questions.explanation: Elisha wept foreseeing Hazael's cruelty, yet this was part of God's providential plan to discipline Israel (2 Kings 8:11-12).

questions.question: On the road to Gaza, Philip converted and baptized a
questions.explanation: God guided Philip to the Ethiopian eunuch at precisely the right moment, showing providential timing in evangelism (Acts 8:26-27).

parental responsibility.name: Parental Responsibility
parental responsibility.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: 'You would bring down my grey hairs with sorrow to Sheol.' Jacob said this to his children because
options: he feared that Benjamin would be lost to him like Joseph
questions.explanation: This is from your 1985 exam, question 4. Jacob expresses deep paternal fear for Benjamin's safety.

questions.question: Samuel's sons were rejected as judges because they
options: were not from the royal family
the Israelites wanted to be like other people who had kings
questions.explanation: From 1985, question 16. Shows consequences of parental failure to discipline children properly.

questions.question: 'Alas, my daughter: you have brought me very low and you have become the cause of great trouble to me for I have opened my mouth to the Lord, and I cannot take back my vow.' Who said this?
questions.explanation: From 1986, question 17. Jephthah's rash vow tragically affected his daughter.

questions.question: 'O Lord of hosts, if thou wilt ... give to thy maidservant a son, then I will give him to the Lord all the days of his life, and no razor shall touch his head.' Who said this?
questions.explanation: From 1988, question 19. Hannah's vow to dedicate her child to God.

questions.question: Elkannah would give Hannah only one portion of the sacrifice because
questions.explanation: From 1991, question 15. Shows spousal support in a difficult situation.

questions.question: 'The LORD give you children by this woman.' Eli offered this prayer because of Hannah's
options: loan of Samuel to the Lord
desire for more children from God
questions.explanation: From 2001, question 5. Recognition of parental dedication of a child to God.

questions.question: The response of Eli after Samuel had told him the Lord's message as regards his sons' acts of blasphemy was that
options: sacrifice would be offered on their behalf
he would call them and rebuke them
God should have mercy on them
He was the LORD, and should do what pleased Him
questions.explanation: From 2003, question 30. Eli's resigned acceptance of God's judgment on his sons.

questions.question: Joseph's brothers decided not to kill him because
options: he was loved by their father
he was their brother and their flesh
he was the first son of his mother
questions.explanation: From 2004, question 36. Shows complex family dynamics and sibling responsibility.

Obedience and disobedience.name: Obedience and Disobedience
Obedience and disobedience.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: 'I repent that I made Saul king.' What incident does this refer to?
options: During Saul's encounter with the Ammonites
When Saul disobeyed God over Amalek
questions.explanation: God regretted making Saul king because he disobeyed the command to completely destroy the Amalekites, sparing King Agag and the best livestock (1 Samuel 15:11).

questions.question: Moses could not enter the Promised Land because he
options: was too old to cross the border
was too busy preparing his successor
did not give due regard to God
questions.explanation: Moses struck the rock at Meribah instead of speaking to it as God commanded, failing to honor God as holy before the people (Numbers 20:12).

questions.question: Whoever touches the 'mountain of God' shall be put to death by
questions.explanation: Strict boundaries were set at Mount Sinai to teach reverence and obedience to God's holiness; violators were to be stoned (Exodus 19:12-13).

questions.question: The sin of the Israelites that led to the punishment by fiery serpents was
options: trying to stone Caleb and Joshua
questions.explanation: The people spoke against God and Moses, complaining about the manna and lack of water, showing ingratitude and rebellion (Numbers 21:5-6).

questions.question: The final consequence of Saul's disobedience to God was his
questions.explanation: Saul's persistent disobedience culminated in his death at the Battle of Mount Gilboa, where he fell on his own sword (1 Samuel 31:4-6).

questions.question: God told Solomon that He would surely tear the kingdom from him and give it to his
questions.explanation: Because Solomon turned to other gods through his foreign wives, God promised to give most of the kingdom to his servant Jeroboam (1 Kings 11:11).

questions.question: Achan, who took some of the devoted things when Jericho fell, was from the tribe of
questions.explanation: Achan's disobedience in taking a Babylonian robe, silver, and gold from Jericho brought defeat to Israel at Ai and death to his family (Joshua 7:1).

questions.topic_focus: Moses' Disobedience at Waters of Meribah
questions.question: In Exodus 17 and Numbers 20, similar incidents of lack of water for the congregation are recorded. A significant difference however, is that in Exodus 17, Moses is commanded to
questions.explanation: At the first Meribah, God told Moses to strike the rock, which he did. At the second Meribah, God told him to speak to the rock, but Moses struck it twice in anger and disobedience (Numbers 20:8).

questions.question: The murmuring of the congregation in the wilderness against Moses and Aaron were an indication of the people's
options: fear of dying by the sword
inability to get to the promise land
questions.explanation: The people's constant complaints showed their lack of faith in God's provision and guidance through His appointed leaders Moses and Aaron.

questions.question: When the glory of the LORD appeared to Moses and Aaron in the wilderness of Zin, the Lord said they should
options: tell the rock before their eyes to yield its water
strike the rock with rod to bring out water for them
fetch water for the people and their cattle
tell the people to go around the rock
questions.explanation: God gave specific instructions to speak to the rock at Meribah, but Moses disobeyed by striking it twice, showing anger rather than trust in God's word.

questions.question: Naaman's leprosy was transferred to Gehazi as a result of
options: the testimony of the maid of Israel
the gifts he received from Naaman
the bath Gehazi took in the river Jordan
questions.explanation: Gehazi disobeyed Elisha's refusal of gifts by lying to Naaman to obtain silver and garments, resulting in Naaman's leprosy transferring to him (2 Kings 5:27).

questions.question: God took the Kingdom from Saul because he
options: did not offer sacrifices to the Lord
disobeyed the Lord by offering burnt sacrifices himself
questions.explanation: Saul presumptuously offered the burnt offering himself instead of waiting for Samuel, violating his role as king and showing impatience and disobedience (1 Samuel 13:8-14).

questions.question: 'Take off the rings of gold which are in the ears of your wives, your sons and your daughters and bring them to me.' This was for
questions.explanation: Aaron collected gold earrings from the people to make a golden calf while Moses was on Mount Sinai, a grave act of idolatry and disobedience (Exodus 32:2-4).

questions.question: God told Moses that the people should gather just a day's portion of bread so that He might test their
questions.explanation: The manna instructions tested Israel's obedience in gathering only what they needed each day and not keeping any overnight except before the Sabbath (Exodus 16:4).

a man after God's own heart.name: A man after God's own heart
a man after God's own heart.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: David's first reaction after he had been rebuked by God through the prophet Nathan for his sin against Uriah was to: (1984)
options: Plead with God to preserve the life of his child by Uriah's wife.
Request that the punishments threatened by God would not come to pass.
Simply wait for whatever God would bring on him.
questions.explanation: David's immediate and heartfelt confession, 'I have sinned against the LORD,' (2 Samuel 12:13) demonstrates the repentant heart that characterized him as a man after God's own heart.

questions.question: 'How is it you were not afraid to put forth your hand to destroy the Lord's anointed?' was said by: (Unnumbered Set)
options: Elijah to Ahab when Ahab sought to kill him.
David to the Amalekite who claimed to have killed Saul.
Joab to Absalom when the latter rebelled against David.
David to Saul when Saul attacked him with a spear.
questions.explanation: This shows David's deep reverence for the sanctity of God's anointed king, even when that king (Saul) was his enemy. It reflects his commitment to God's sovereign choices (2 Samuel 1:14).

decision making.name: Decision Making
decision making.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: When Joseph discovered that his betrothed Mary was with child, he decided to divorce her quietly because: (1985)
options: Mary was too tender and lovely.
The angel warned Joseph not to be harsh on Mary.
questions.explanation: Joseph's decision-making was guided by his righteous character. He sought to obey the law while also acting with mercy, showing careful and compassionate judgment (Matthew 1:19).

questions.question: 'Your father made our yoke heavy. Now therefore lighten the hard service of your father... and we will serve you.' This request was made to: (1984)
questions.explanation: Rehoboam's decision to reject the elders' wise counsel and follow the harsh advice of his peers led to the division of the kingdom, showing the catastrophic consequences of poor leadership decisions (1 Kings 12:13-14).

greed.name: Greed and its effects
greed.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: Achan, who took some of the devoted things when Jericho fell, was from the tribe of: (1987)
questions.explanation: Achan's greed led him to take a beautiful cloak, silver, and gold from Jericho, which was devoted to destruction. His sin brought defeat upon Israel and death to himself and his family (Joshua 7:1, 24-25).

questions.question: Naaman's leprosy was transferred to Gehazi as a result of: (1999)
options: The testimony of the maid of Israel.
The gifts he received from Naaman.
The bath Gehazi took in the river Jordan.
questions.explanation: Driven by greed, Gehazi lied to Naaman to obtain gifts that his master Elisha had refused. His covetousness resulted in him being struck with Naaman's leprosy (2 Kings 5:27).

Supremacy of God.name: The Supremacy of God
Supremacy of God.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: And at the time of the offering of the oblation, Elijah prayed, '...O Lord, answer me, that this people may know that thou, O Lord, art God...' What happened after this prayer? (1989)
options: The fire of the Lord fell.
questions.explanation: God's supreme power was demonstrated when fire from heaven consumed the sacrifice, the altar, and even the water in the trench, proving He alone is God (1 Kings 18:38).

questions.question: Who was the prophet who proved on Mount Carmel that Yahweh is greater than Baal? (Unnumbered Set)
questions.explanation: The contest on Mount Carmel, orchestrated by the prophet Elijah, was a definitive public demonstration of the supremacy of Yahweh over the Canaanite god Baal.

religious reforms.name: Religious reforms in Judah
religious reforms.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: The incident which inspired King Josiah to undertake a reform was the: (1989)
options: Discovery of the book of the law.
questions.explanation: Josiah's comprehensive religious reforms were triggered by the discovery of the Book of the Law during temple repairs, which made him realize how far Judah had strayed (2 Kings 22:8-13).

questions.question: What did king Josiah do to the altar that was erected by Jeroboam at Bethel? (2004)
options: He broke its stones into pieces.
questions.explanation: As part of his reforms, Josiah desecrated the pagan altar at Bethel, fulfilling a prophecy made centuries earlier. He broke down the altar and burned the Asherah pole (2 Kings 23:15).

Judah.name: Concern for Judah
Judah.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: 'All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the Lord has laid on him the iniquity of us all.' This messianic prophecy was made by: (1989)
questions.explanation: This verse from Isaiah 53:6 is part of the Suffering Servant song, expressing profound concern for Judah's spiritual condition and pointing to God's redemptive plan through the Messiah.

questions.question: The prophet who proclaimed a new covenant of God with Israel and Judah was: (1984)
questions.explanation: Jeremiah prophesied a future new covenant where God's law would be written on hearts, not stone, showing God's enduring concern and plan for Judah's restoration (Jeremiah 31:31).

faith courage and protection.name: Faith, Courage and Protection
faith courage and protection.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: '...If it be so, our God whom we serve is able to deliver us from the burning fiery furnace...' The statement above portrays Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego as: (2000)
questions.explanation: Their declaration demonstrates absolute faith in God's power to protect them, coupled with the courage to accept death rather than compromise their worship (Daniel 3:17-18).

questions.question: 'But I will be with you and you will smite the Midianites as one man' was said by God to: (1985)
questions.explanation: God called the fearful Gideon a 'mighty man of valor' and promised His presence, which gave Gideon the courage to lead Israel against the Midianites (Judges 6:12, 16).

nineveh.name: God's message to Nineveh
nineveh.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: God called Jonah and sent him to the people of Nineveh to: (2004)
options: Pray to Him for their forgiveness.
questions.explanation: God's message to Nineveh, delivered through Jonah, was a proclamation of impending judgment due to their wickedness: 'Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown!' (Jonah 3:4).

questions.question: 'And the Lord God appointed a plant, and made it come up over Jonah...' The statement above taught Jonah that: (2000)
options: The repentance of the Ninevites would be short-lived.
His assignment would not last long.
questions.explanation: The lesson of the plant (and the worm) was to teach Jonah about God's sovereign right to have compassion on whomever He chooses, including the great city of Nineveh (Jonah 4:10-11).

social justice.name: Social Justice, True religion and Divine Love
social justice.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: Amos told the Israelites that they have turned justice into: (1999)
questions.explanation: Amos condemned the corruption of the legal system, declaring, 'You turn justice into wormwood'—a bitter, poisonous plant symbolizing the perversion of what should be good and right (Amos 5:7).

questions.question: The main lesson of Hosea's teachings is that God: (2000)
options: Will pour His spirit on all flesh.
Will create a new heart in His people.
questions.explanation: Hosea's core message, echoed by Jesus, is that God desires 'steadfast love and not sacrifice, the knowledge of God rather than burnt offerings' (Hosea 6:6). True religion is relational, not merely ritualistic.

holiness.name: Holiness and Divine call
holiness.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: Which prophet gave this cry? 'Woe is me! For I am lost, for I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips.' (1984)
questions.explanation: Isaiah's vision of the holy God (the 'Holy, holy, holy' of Isaiah 6) immediately convicted him of his own and his people's sinfulness, a foundational experience of his prophetic call.

questions.question: How did God convince Jeremiah of his divine call? (1999)
options: He spoke to him directly from heaven.
He sent a prophet to inform him.
questions.explanation: God touched Jeremiah's mouth, symbolically setting him apart and putting His words in the prophet's mouth, consecrating him for the holy task of being a prophet to the nations (Jeremiah 1:9).

punishment and hope.name: Punishment and Hope
punishment and hope.category: Themes from the Division of the Kingdom to the Return from Exile and the Prophets

questions.question: The vision of 'dry bones' teaches that: (1989)
options: There will be a resurrection of the body.
There will be a new creation.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel's vision of the valley of dry bones was a prophecy of national hope. It symbolized God's power to spiritually resurrect and restore the exiled house of Israel to their land (Ezekiel 37:11-14).

questions.question: Which prophet made this prophecy of Zion's happy future? 'And the ransomed of the Lord shall return, and come to Zion with singing...' (1986)
questions.explanation: This promise of joyful return from exile is a classic message of hope from Isaiah, assuring Judah of future restoration despite the impending punishment (Isaiah 35:10).
